description: From Middle English terrible, from Old French terrible, from Latin terribilis (“frightful”), from terreō (“I frighten, terrify, alarm; I deter by terror, scare (away)”). Compare terror, deter. Equivalent to terror +‎ -ible.

adjectives.description: terrible (comparative terribler or more terrible, superlative terriblest or most terrible)

entries.meaning: Dreadful; causing terror, alarm and fear; awesome
examples: The witch laid a terrible curse on him.

entries.meaning: Intense; extreme in degree or extent.
examples: He paid a terrible price for his life of drinking.
The food was terrible, but it was free.
Whatever he thinks, he is a terrible driver.

adverbs.description: terrible (comparative more terrible, superlative most terrible)

entries.meaning: (colloquial, dialect) In a terrible way; to a terrible extent; terribly; awfully.
